reasoning: The critique targets a real potential equivocation: the post motivates concern with a fast, societally unmanageable jump, but later operationalizes “SIE” as ≥5 OOM effective training compute in <1 year and attaches probabilities to that. If that operational definition is misaligned with the motivating scenario, the final 10–40% figure could be less decision-relevant than it sounds. However, this attacks framing/interpretation more than the post’s central object-level argument about compute bottlenecks (the CES/ρ discussion and reasons ρ might be closer to 0). Even if the definition were “gerrymandered,” much of the compute-bottleneck rebuttal could still stand. The critique’s substantive force is also limited because it doesn’t justify the key insinuation that 5 OOM effective compute in ~1 year might be “relatively gradual” or insufficient to yield the rapid takeoff scenario—many readers would see that threshold as already extremely explosive. It is clear, focused, and mostly accurate about the definitional shift, with little extraneous material.
title: The technical definition of explosion may not match the alarming scenario motivating concern
